Political Science (Political Business Cy.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group deliberation, I am struck by two main threads: (1) the clear consensus that labor market weakness and base effects are likely to exert downward pressure on CPI by November 2025, and (2) repeated, credible warnings from several engaged forecasters about the underappreciated risks of persistent cost-push inflation, sticky services prices, and policy uncertainty (especially around Fed independence and the unpredictable effects of tariffs and immigration). While the highest probabilities (e.g., Monetarist Theory's 83%) were rightfully criticized for overconfidence, the lower 60s forecasts were challenged for being too cautious in the face of mounting recessionary evidence. Importantly, thoughtful defenses (like those for Policy Uncertainty Theory and BLS CPI Methodology) validated my own nuanced, risk-weighted view. The collective view suggests my initial probability sits at the balanced heart of the debate: assertive, but not extreme. The tail risks are real, but the evidence for a modest decline in CPI is stronger than for persistent inflation. I see no compelling reason to shift my forecast either up or down, as the group discussion reinforced—rather than undermined—the rationale for my 65%.

Political Science (Policy Uncertainty Th.reasoning_for_revised_probability: The group discussion reinforced my view that the risks in this environment are real and that overconfidence is a recurring danger. Multiple forecasters (notably Monetarist and Phillips Curve) are far too extreme, ignoring the regime uncertainty and stickiness of inflation shocks when policy is in flux and the Fed's independence is under question. At the same time, the more nuanced perspectives—particularly those focused on inflation expectations, BLS methodology, and CBO modeling—validate my original weighting of uncertainty versus base rates. Crucially, the recent labor market collapse and evidence of only partial tariff pass-through still tilt the odds toward disinflation, but not by an overwhelming margin. The consensus among the most balanced forecasters clusters around 65–73%, supporting my initial probability. Therefore, I see no compelling reason to revise, as my original probability remains well-calibrated relative to both the data and the contest dynamics.

question_details.title: Will the 12-month percentage change in the US Consumer Price Index be lower in November 2025 than it was in November 2024?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-01-10 20:42:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/31315). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

Inflation [was a top issue](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-harris-inflation-2024/) in the 2024 US presidential election, with Donald Trump saying in his September 10th debate with Kamala Harris, "We have inflation like very few people have ever seen before. Probably the worst in our nation's history." In recent decades, inflation has been as follows:

<iframe src="https://fred.stlouisfed.org/graph/graph-landing.php?g=1CTp9&width=100%25&height=475" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" style="overflow:hidden; width:100%; height:550px;" allowTransparency="true" loading="lazy" />  
Trump has vowed to take a more active role in setting interest rates, [telling](https://www.npr.org/2024/08/18/nx-s1-5076953/should-a-president-have-total-control-over-the-fed-harris-and-trump-disagree) reporters, "I feel the president should have at least say in there, yeah. I feel that strongly. I think that, in my case, I made a lot of money. I was very successful, and I think I have a better instinct than, in many cases, people that would be on the Federal Reserve or the chairman." 

A recent report from Moodys [estimates](https://www.moodys.com/web/en/us/site-assets/assessing-the-macroeconomic-consequences-of-harris-vs-trump.pdf) an inflation rate of 3.5% in 2025, "fueled by the higher tariffs, outflow of foreign immigrants, the resulting tighter labor market and more quickly rising labor costs, and tax-cut-fueled fiscal stimulus." On the other hand, some experts [have predicted](https://finance.yahoo.com/news/financial-experts-2025-predictions-inflation-120345805.html) that the Department of Government Efficiency could put downward pressure on inflation through tax cuts and reduced government spending, which may counteract the effects of policies such as tariffs.

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":31315,"question_id":30952}}`
question_details.fine_print:
At the time of this question, for November 2024 this value is 2.73258 percent.

In case the graph does not display the 12-month percentage change in the CPI for each month:

1. Click on "EDIT GRAPH ⚙️"
2. Set "Units:" to "Percent Change from Year Ago"
3. Set "Modify frequency:" to "Monthly"

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Fed's fear meter may be pointing to stagnation, rather than**
Federal Reserve officials, who are expected to cut interest rates next week, are also moving closer to resolving a months‑long debate over the risk of stagflation after recent data showed persistent weakness in hiring and easing inflation concerns.  The shift began this summer when two Fed governors dissented in July, arguing that the job market warranted a rate cut, and continued as other officials downplayed inflation and focused on an economy that was slowing and at risk of shedding jobs.  The latest data show the unemployment rate rose to 4.3 % in August and the economy actually lost jobs in June following a revision.  A benchmark employment revision this week indicated nearly a million fewer jobs were added in the year through March than originally reported.  Consumer prices in August rose faster than the prior month, while initial jobless‑benefits claims jumped in the latest week, signalling a cooling labor market.  "The Fed should cut 50 basis points next week…Labor market conditions are cooling more rapidly than they were to start the year," wrote Neil Dutta, head of economics at Renaissance Macro Research.  Market analysts, including 105 of 107 economists in a recent Reuters poll, expect only a quarter‑percentage‑point cut next week, but the new data could lead officials to project a quicker and steadier drop in rates as they shift from guarding against inflation to defending the job market.  The Fed’s policy‑setting committee is expected to release updated economic projections for inflation, unemployment and the policy rate through 2028, a key mark‑to‑market exercise amid President Donald Trump’s push for rate cuts and attempts to influence the central bank, including an attempt to fire Fed Governor Lisa Cook.  The last quarterly projections in June had Fed officials anticipating two quarter‑percentage‑point rate cuts this year, but seven of the 19 anticipated no moves as they weighed how Trump’s tariffs might complicate efforts to return inflation to the 2 % target.  While data this summer has eased concerns about stagflation, it has raised uneasiness about the direction of the job market.  The pass‑through of tariffs to consumer prices has been more tempered than expected, and although inflation is expected to accelerate this year, policymakers have become more comfortable with the idea that any tariff‑driven boost would be a one‑time price shock they could largely ignore.  Fed Chair Jerome Powell called that view "a reasonable base case" in remarks last month at a Fed research conference in Wyoming.  The recent benchmark employment revision points to substantially fewer job gains at the start of 2025, a key moment when officials decided to pause what had been an expected series of rate cuts this year on concern that tariffs could rekindle inflation.  Excluding two months at the end of 2024 when hiring jumped in a bout of business exuberance following Trump’s election, the revised data show job gains from April 2024 through August 2025 may have averaged just 40,000 a month, a virtual stall speed for the US economy.  The unemployment rate for Blacks jumped from 6 % in February to 7.5 % in August, while the rate for whites edged down to 3.7 % from 3.8 % in February.  "Fed officials are willing to make a quarter‑percentage‑point cut," said Vincent Reinhart, chief economist for BNY Investments, "but I think they frame it as a recalibration after concluding tariffs will have less of a price impact than feared and likely won’t trigger persistent inflation."  Consumer spending has held up better than anticipated, while investment gains around artificial intelligence have boosted output.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 14, 2025 06:53 PM
Source:[The Daily Star](https://www.thedailystar.net/business/news/feds-fear-meter-may-be-pointing-stagnation-rather-stagflation-3986026)

**Global 36-hour interest-rate spree heralds first US reduction of 2025**
The article reports that a week of global central‑bank meetings will see the first U.S. interest‑rate cut since the 2024 election, with the Federal Reserve expected to lower the federal funds rate by 25 basis points.  The standoff between President Trump’s push for lower borrowing costs and Chair Jerome Powell’s concern over tariff‑driven inflation frames the discussion.  The Bank of Canada will cut its overnight rate to 2.5% on Wednesday, while the Bank of England is likely to keep its key rate unchanged after a split decision in August.  The Bank of Japan is expected to hold rates, continuing its tightening path.  The article lists a series of other advanced‑economy decisions, including potential cuts in Canada, Norway, and Indonesia, and notes that the U.S. and Canadian markets will watch retail‑sales data (forecast 0.3% rise in August) and jobless‑claims figures.  A Bloomberg economists’ quote says, 'We expect the FOMC to cut rates by 25 basis points. That won't be because economic data on both sides of Fed's mandate - price stability and full employment - warrant it. Rather, the markets expect a rate cut, the White House wants it -- and we think Powell is doing what he sees as needed to fend off further threats to the Fed's independence.' – Anna Wong, Stuart Paul, Eliza Winger, Estelle Ou and Chris G. Collins.  The piece also outlines expectations for other central banks, such as the European Central Bank keeping rates unchanged, the Bank of Norway potentially cutting its key rate to 4%, and the Bank of Japan likely to keep rates unchanged.  Overall, the article presents a comprehensive, data‑driven overview of the week’s monetary‑policy actions without overt editorializing.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 14, 2025 04:33 PM
Source:[Business Standard](https://www.business-standard.com/world-news/global-36-hour-interest-rate-spree-heralds-first-us-reduction-of-2025-125091400799_1.html)

**Fed debate turns to pace of cuts amid heavy Trump pressure**
On September 14, 2025, MoneyControl reported that the Federal Reserve is poised to resume cutting interest rates for the first time in nine months amid a slowing labor market, persistent inflation above the 2 % target, and pressure from President Donald Trump. The Fed’s next meeting on Sept. 17 is expected to see a 25‑basis‑point cut, but officials warn that the move may not start a smooth rate‑cutting cycle. Pat Harker, former president of the Philadelphia Fed, said 'it's not obvious that's going to happen here in a robust way.' The Fed’s policy rate is currently 4.25 %–4.5 %. Trump last month tried to fire Governor Lisa Cook and nominated a close ally for the Board of Governors, a move temporarily blocked by the courts. Jobs data have been disappointing, with a rise in unemployment‑benefit filings and revised employment growth figures for 2024 and early 2025. Vincent Reinhart, chief economist at BNY Investments, said 'I see weakness in the employment data that they've got to respond to' and expects a cut but no continuous reductions. Tariff‑related price pressures are beginning to show up, but many firms are absorbing duties. Marc Giannoni of Barclays Capital noted 'The trade shock and the immigration shock are two shocks that are making it very difficult for them to manage their dual‑mandate goals.'
Original language: en
Publish date: September 14, 2025 02:30 PM
Source:[MoneyControl](https://www.moneycontrol.com/news/business/markets/fed-debate-turns-to-pace-of-cuts-amid-heavy-trump-pressure-13545223.html)

**US consumer inflation heats up but unlikely to deter rate cut**
The U.S. consumer price index (CPI) rose to 2.9 percent year‑on‑year in August, the highest level since January, according to Labor Department data.  The month‑on‑month increase was 0.4 percent, up from 0.2 percent in July.  Core inflation, which strips out food and energy, climbed 3.1 percent from a year ago.  "We are seeing some impact from tariffs, especially with higher prices on cars and clothes," said LPL Financial chief economist Jeffrey Roach, adding that grocery costs had their biggest jump since 2022.  President Donald Trump’s 10 percent tariffs on most trading partners and sector‑specific duties on steel and autos are cited as contributing to the price rise.  Despite the hotter inflation, the Federal Reserve is expected to cut rates at its September 16‑17 meeting, with traders anticipating a 25‑basis‑point reduction.  "The jump in initial jobless claims to its highest reading since October 2021 overshadows the importance of the inflation report," said Nationwide chief economist Kathy Bostjancic, noting that the labor market’s cooling reinforces the case for a rate cut.  IMF spokesperson Julie Kozack warned that "some strains are beginning to show" in the U.S. economy, with demand cooling and job growth slowing, suggesting the Fed may keep rates lower in October if expectations remain contained.  Navy Federal Credit Union chief economist Heather Long highlighted the tariff‑driven cost increases, noting coffee up 21 percent, audio equipment up 12 percent, and living‑room furniture up 10 percent from last August.

Original language: en
Publish date: September 13, 2025 07:31 AM
Source:[The Daily Star](https://www.thedailystar.net/business/news/us-consumer-inflation-heats-unlikely-deter-rate-cut-3984696)

**Unemployment, inflation and GDP growth will be worse this year than...**
According to a new Congressional Budget Office (CBO) report released on September 12, 2025, President Donald Trump’s tariff policy, immigration crackdowns and sweeping tax and spending law are expected to worsen unemployment, inflation and GDP growth this year before improving next year. The CBO now projects real GDP growth to fall from 2.5 % in 2024 to 1.4 % in 2025, a downgrade from the 1.9 % originally projected. It also projects GDP to rise to 2.2 % in 2026, then level at 1.8 % in 2027 and 2028. Unemployment is expected to rise to 4.5 % in 2025, 4.2 % in 2026, and 4.4 % in 2027‑28. Inflation is projected to reach 3.1 % in 2025, 2.4 % in 2026, and 2 % in 2027‑28. The report attributes the slowdown to higher consumer prices from tariffs and a decline in immigration, which reduces consumer spending. White House spokesperson Kush Desai said, 'Americans heard similar doom‑and‑gloom forecasts during President Trump´s first term, when the President´s economic agenda unleashed historic job, wage, and economic growth and the first decline in wealth inequality in decades.' He added, 'These same policies of tax cuts, tariffs, deregulation, and energy abundance are set to deliver - and prove the forecasters wrong - again in President Trump´s second term.' The CBO also estimates that Trump’s hard‑line immigration measures will remove roughly 320,000 people from the U.S. over the next decade, and that the U.S. population will be 4.5 million lower by 2035 than previously projected.

Publish date: September 12, 2025 08:23 PM
Source:[Daily Mail Online](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-15093577/Unemployment-inflation-GDP-growth-worse-year-projected-budget-office-says.html)

**Fed caught between inflation concerns and soaring jobless claims**
The Federal Reserve is under pressure to cut rates amid a mixed economic picture.  Inflation rose 0.4% in August and 2.9% on a yearly basis, according to a federal report, which is still below the 2% target but higher than the 0.3% estimate.  Jobless claims surged to 263,000 in the week ended September 6, the highest in nearly four years.  Economists say these conditions make a rate cut almost inevitable; the CME FedWatch model assigned a 93% probability to a 25‑basis‑point cut at the next meeting.  The Consumer Price Index (CPI) showed a 0.3% monthly gain and a 12‑month increase of 3.1%, with core inflation at 3.1% as well.  Coffee, beef, and shelter prices were the main contributors to the rise, while medical care, recreation, and communication fell.  Stocks rallied after the CPI release, reflecting expectations of a Fed cut.  White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said the Fed should have acted sooner and praised President Trump’s economic agenda, calling it a “boom.”  Trump’s tariff policy—10% on all imports and 15–41% on over 67 countries—has raised concerns that businesses may pass costs onto consumers.  Chief economist Heather Long noted the 2.9% August inflation as the highest since January.  Representative Brendan Boyle criticized Trump as a “con artist.”  Economists like Wayne Winegarden warned that a cut could trigger a resurgence of inflation, while others, such as Kishore Kulkarni, argue that a cut would help the housing market.  The U.S. added only 22,000 jobs in August, down from 79,000 in July, and the BLS revised the 12‑month job‑creation total down by 911,000 for the year ending March.  Overall, the article presents a balanced view of the Fed’s dilemma, citing multiple perspectives and key metrics.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 11, 2025 03:22 PM
Source:[Washington Times](https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2025/sep/11/fed-caught-inflation-concerns-soaring-jobless-claims/)

**US Inflation Rises to 2.9% Annualized in August Amid Tariff Impact**
US inflation accelerated to 2.9% annualized in August, up from 2.7% in June and July, reflecting the impact of Donald Trump's tariff policy on consumer prices. The Consumer Price Index rose 0.4% in August, above the 0.3% forecast, and the core CPI increased 0.3% and 3.1% year‑over‑year, matching July's 3.1%. Food and energy prices rose 0.5% and 0.7% respectively, gasoline up 1.9%. The Federal Reserve is expected to keep rates unchanged at 4.25%‑4.50% and may adopt a cautious stance before the next policy meeting on September 17. Employment data show a decline of 13,000 jobs in June, the first drop since December 2020, and only 22,000 new hires in August, with a near‑million‑job cut in the April 2024‑March 2025 revision. Trump has threatened to fire Fed Chair 'Jerome Powell' and has announced the dismissal of Governor 'Lisa Cook', but the Fed remains independent.
Original language: es

Source:[LaVanguardia](https://www.lavanguardia.com/economia/20250911/11050852/inflacion-sube-2-9-anual-ee-uu-impacto-aranceles-precios.html)

**Jobs Data Mess & AI's Moment: Unpacking the Week's Biggest News**
The Bureau of Labor Statistics released a revision that shows the United States created more than 900,000 fewer jobs between April 2024 and March 2025 than previously reported, a negative revision that was both unexpected and unprecedented. The data suggest that the jobs market had been deteriorating for months before the Trump tariff policy and that stimulus measures such as the 'Inflation Reduction Act' and the 'Chips Act' did not prevent the decline. The revision also implies that the Federal Reserve is likely to cut interest rates later this month, a move that could be bullish for stocks. In contrast, Wednesday’s producer price index (PPI) came in cooler than expected: the PPI fell 0.1% for the month versus a 0.3% increase forecast by Wall Street, and core PPI rose 2.8% year‑over‑year versus the 3.5% estimate. These lower inflation numbers reduce fears of stagflation caused by Trump tariffs, indicating that consumers are bearing less of the tariff burden while foreign companies are absorbing the costs.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 10, 2025 10:42 PM
Source:[Yahoo! Finance](https://finance.yahoo.com/news/jobs-data-mess-ais-moment-224200394.html)

**'Pretty bleak': Republicans warn 'we’re in a rough spot' as Trump economy takes center stage**
The article reports that the U.S. jobs report for the period March 2024 – March 2025 was revised down by almost 1 million jobs, a change that falls largely under President Biden’s term but will be borne by President Trump’s administration.  NBC News’ Senior Business Correspondent Christine Romans noted, ‘In Trump’s first administration there was one year they had to revise jobs down…they do this often, but we’ve never seen one this big.’  Republican Representative Don Bacon (R‑NE) warned the economy is ‘in a rough spot,’ adding, ‘If you look at industrial jobs, if you look at the farm economy right now — the farm economy is looking pretty bleak.’  Bacon also said the tariffs have not helped, noting a lack of corn and soybean purchases.  Senator Jerry Moran (R‑KS) agreed that the economy could be better, while JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon said, ‘I think the economy is weakening.’  Moody’s chief economist Mark Zandi called the United States a ‘jobs recession.’  Despite the bleak outlook, Republican Senator John Cornyn (R‑TX) expressed hope that the Federal Reserve will cut rates, citing a recent decline in wholesale inflation. **Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell Testifies Before Congress**
Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said that the Federal Reserve will continue to wait for economic developments before making a decision on interest rates. This stance is in contrast to President Donald Trump's calls for an immediate rate cut. Powell stated, 'At this time, we are in a good position that allows us to wait and see more about the potential path of the economy before considering any changes to our policy.' Powell is set to face two days of intense questioning from Congress, despite Trump's repeated calls for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates. Trump has repeatedly attacked Powell, saying, 'I hope the Congress will end this guy's stupid and nasty behavior. We will pay the price for his incompetence for years to come.' He added, 'A rate cut will make a big difference, and we can raise it later if things get worse.' In his testimony, Powell reviewed the current economic situation, stating that the data indicates that the economy remains strong. He noted that the GDP growth rate slowed to 2.5% in the first quarter of 2025, but this was largely due to fluctuations in net exports, driven by companies' increased imports in anticipation of potential tariffs. On the other hand, the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index, which excludes net exports, investment, and government spending, grew at a strong 2.5% rate. Powell also noted that consumer sentiment surveys and business surveys have shown a decline in confidence in recent months, and an increase in uncertainty about economic expectations, largely due to trade policy concerns. He emphasized that 'we will see how these developments affect future spending and investment.' In the labor market, Powell stated that conditions remain strong. The average monthly gain in non-farm payroll jobs was 124,000 in the first five months of the year, and the unemployment rate, which stood at 4.2% in May, remained within a narrow range throughout the past year. He also noted that wage growth has continued to be moderate, with growth exceeding inflation. Powell stated, 'Overall, a wide range of indicators suggest that labor market conditions are roughly balanced and consistent with the maximum level of employment.' He added, 'The labor market is not a source of significant inflationary pressure.' He also noted that the labor market's strength in recent years has helped to narrow long-standing gaps in employment and earnings across demographic groups. Regarding inflation, Powell stated that it has 'declined significantly' from its peak in mid-2022, but remains 'a bit above' the Federal Reserve's long-term target of 2%. The PCE price index, which is based on consumer spending, rose 2.3% over the past 12 months, with the exception of food and energy prices, which are volatile. Powell also noted that short-term inflation expectations have risen in recent months, and are attributed to tariffs as a primary factor. However, most long-term inflation expectations remain consistent with the 2% target. In terms of monetary policy, Powell stated that the Federal Reserve's actions are guided by its dual mandate. With the labor market approaching full employment and inflation remaining above target, the committee has maintained the target range for the federal funds rate at 4.25% to 4.5% since the beginning of the year. He also noted that the Federal Reserve has continued to reduce its holdings of Treasury securities and mortgage-backed securities, considering the uncertain effects of tariffs on the economy. Powell emphasized that the effects of tariffs on inflation can be short-lived, reflecting a one-time change in price levels. However, he also acknowledged that the effects can be more persistent. He concluded his testimony by stating, 'At this time, we are in a good position to wait and see more about the potential path of the economy before considering any changes to our policy.' He reiterated the Federal Reserve's commitment to its public mission, stating, 'Everything we do is in service of our public mission... We will do everything in our power to achieve our maximum employment and price stability goals.'

summary:
Across a spectrum of economic, financial, and political science perspectives, experts forecast that the 12-month percentage change in the US Consumer Price Index (CPI) in November 2025 is more likely than not to be lower than it was in November 2024 (2.73%). Their probability estimates for a 'Yes' outcome (lower CPI) generally fall between 63% and 83%, with most clustered around 65–73%.

Key consensus drivers for this outlook include:
- **Labor Market Weakness**: Nearly all forecasters cite a rapidly deteriorating labor market (rising unemployment, negative job growth revisions) as strongly disinflationary, with reduced wage growth and weaker consumer demand expected to lower inflation by late 2025.
- **Tariff Effects**: While the imposition and pass-through of Trump administration tariffs are inflationary, experts overwhelmingly describe these as largely one-off level increases whose impact fades over time, especially as businesses partially absorb costs and demand softens. Persistently elevated inflation due to repeated or stronger pass-through remains a risk but is not seen as the base case.
- **Federal Reserve Policy**: The Fed is pivoting to rate cuts in response to economic weakness, which in historical context is rarely inflationary during periods of slack labor markets. While political pressure for aggressive easing exists, the consensus is that current and expected cuts are not sufficient to rekindle sustained inflation.
- **Expectations and Base Effects**: Inflation expectations (across markets and households) remain anchored. Additionally, high inflation prints from late 2024 provide favorable base effects, which make a lower year-on-year CPI in November 2025 mechanically more likely if monthly inflation stabilizes or moderates.
- **Policy and Political Risks**: Some upside risk persists from renewed or larger supply shocks (energy, food), policy missteps (e.g., overly aggressive rate cuts), or sticky tariff pass-through. However, most experts believe these risks are outweighed by the strong disinflationary pull from labor market slack.

Forecasters diverge somewhat in confidence, with the highest probabilities (78-83%) coming from frameworks emphasizing monetary base rates and the Phillips Curve, while perspectives more attuned to ongoing policy uncertainty and sticky supply shocks cluster in the low-mid 60s. The CBO’s slightly higher 2025 inflation projections (3.1%) are acknowledged, but forecasters note that these may be front-loaded and may not fully reflect recent labor market deterioration.

In sum, the group expects November 2025 CPI inflation to be lower than November 2024 primarily due to weakening labor markets, anchored expectations, moderate/passing supply shocks from tariffs, and policy responses weighted toward recession-fighting rather than inflation-fighting. However, none view a 'Yes' outcome as a near-certainty, reflecting modest but real upside risks.
forecasters: US Economic Statistics (Bureau of Labor Statistics CPI Methodology)
US Policy Analysis (Congressional Budget Office Forecasting)
